content.text:
# Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama

The Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama is a Golden Globe Award that was first awarded by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association as a separate category in 1951. Previously, there was a single award for "Best Actress in a Motion Picture", but the splitting allowed for recognition of it and the Best Actress – Comedy or Musical.
The formal title has varied since its inception. In 2005, it was officially called "Best Performance by an Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama". As of 2013, the wording is "Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama".
Winners and nominees
† Indicates the Academy Award winner
is the first winner in the category for The Song of Bernadette (1943).]]
won three times for Gaslight (1944), ''The Bells of St. Mary's (1945), and Anastasia (1956).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Ingrid Bergman in 1944.]]
won twice consecutively for Sister Kenny (1946) and Mourning Becomes Electra (1947).]]
won for The Heiress (1949).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Olivia de Havilland circa 1945.]]
won for Roman Holiday (1953).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Audrey Hepburn in 1956.]]
won for The Country Girl (1954).|alt=Black-and-white photo publicity of Grace Kelly from MGM and before her 1956 marriage.]]
received two nominations and won once; she was also the first non-English native speaking actress and first Italian woman to win the award.]]
won twice for The Three Faces of Eve (1957) and Rachel, Rachel (1968).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Joanne Woodward from MGM.]]
won once from four nominations for her role in Suddenly, Last Summer (1959).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Elizabeth Taylor circa late 1950s.]]
won for Sunrise at Campobello (1960).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Greer Garson in the 1940s.]]
won twice for Summer and Smoke (1961) and Sweet Bird of Youth (1962).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Geraldine Page in 1956.]]
won for The Pumpkin Eater (1964).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Anne Bancroft in 1952.]]
won for The Emigrants (1972).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Liv Ullmann in 1966.]]
won for A Woman Under the Influence (1974).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Gena Rowlands in 1967.]]
won for One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975).]]
won three times from five nominations for her roles in Klute (1971), Julia (1977), and Coming Home (1978).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Jane Fonda in 1963.]]
won twice for Norma Rae (1979) and Places in the Heart (1984).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Sally Field in 1981.]]
Won for Ordinary People (1980)]]
has received 14 nominations for this category, winning three times for her roles in The French Lieutenant's Woman (1981), Sophie's Choice (1982), and The Iron Lady (2011).|alt=Photo of Meryl Streep circa 1976 and 1979.]]
won twice for Terms of Endearment (1983) and Madame Sousatzka (1988).|alt=Black-and-white publicity photo of Shirley MacLaine in 1960.]]
won for The Color Purple (1985).|alt=Photo of Whoopi Goldberg in 2006.]]
won for Children of a Lesser God (1986)]]
won for Anna (1987)]]
won for Gorillas in the Mist (1988).]]
won twice for The Accused (1988) and The Silence of the Lambs (1991).|alt=Photo of Jodie Foster in 1995.]]
won for The Fabulous Baker Boys (1989).|alt=Photo of Michelle Pfeiffer in 2007.]]
won for Misery (1990).|alt=Photo of Kathy Bates at the 2015 San Diego Comic-Con.]]
won for Howards End (1992).|alt=Photo of Emma Thompson in 2022.]]
won for The Piano (1993).|alt=Photo of Holly Hunter at the 2015 San Diego Comic-Con.]]
won for Blue Sky (1994).|alt=Photo of Jessica Lange in 2008.]]
won for Casino (1995).|alt=Photo of Sharon Stone at the 2017 Celebrity Fight Night XXIII in Phoenix, Arizona.]]
won for her portrayal of Queen Victoria in Mrs Brown (1997).|alt=Photo of Judi Dench at the 60th British Academy Film Awards in 2007.]]
won three times for Elizabeth (1998), Blue Jasmine (2013), and Tár (2022).|alt=Photo of Cate Blanchett at the 2018 Cannes Film Festival.]]
won twice for Boys Don't Cry (1999) and Million Dollar Baby (2004).|alt=Photo of Hilary Swank at the 28th Tokyo International Film Festival in 2015.]]
won for playing the title role in Erin Brockovich (2000).|alt=Photo of Julia Roberts at the 2011 Tribeca Film Festival.]]
won for In the Bedroom (2001).]]
won twice for The Hours (2002) and Being the Ricardos (2021).|alt=Photo of Nicole Kidman at the 2017 Cannes Film Festival.]]
won for her portrayal of Aileen Wuornos in Monster (2003).|alt=Photo of Charlize Theron at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival.]]
won for her portrayal of Queen Elizabeth II in The Queen (2006).|alt=Photo of Helen Mirren at the 2014 Moët British Independent Film Awards.]]
won for Revolutionary Road (2008).|alt=Photo of Kate Winslet in 2017.]]
won for Black Swan (2010).|alt=Photo of Natalie Portman at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival.]]
won for Zero Dark Thirty (2012).|alt=Photo of Jessica Chastain at the 2015 San Diego Comic-Con.]]
won for Still Alice (2014).|alt=Photo of Julianne Moore at the 2009 Venice International Film Festival.]]
won for Room (2015).|alt=Photo of Brie Larson at the National Air and Space Museum.]]
won for Elle (2016).|alt=Photo of Isabelle Huppert at the 2017 Cannes Film Festival.]]
won for Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri (2017).|alt=Photo of Frances McDormand at 21st Annual Screen Actors Guild Awards.]]
won for The Wife (2018).|alt=Photo of Glenn Close at the premiere of "Guardians of the Galaxy" at the El Capitan Theater in Hollywood on July 21, 2014.]]
won for Judy (2019).|alt=Zellweger at the 2010 Berlin International Film Festival]]
won for The United States vs. Billie Holiday (2020).|alt=Day in 2016]]
won for Killers of the Flower Moon (2023).|alt=Actress Lily Gladstone at the 2024 Cannes Film Festival.]]

Firsts
* Anouk Aimée became the first actress to win for a foreign language/non-English language performance in 1967.
* Whoopi Goldberg became the first actress of African descent to win in 1986.
* Marlee Matlin became the first deaf actress to win in 1987.
* Jodie Foster, Shirley MacLaine, and Sigourney Weaver became the only actresses ever to win Golden Globes in a three-way tie in 1988.
* Lily Gladstone became the first actress of Native American heritage to win in 2024.
* Fernanda Torres became the first Latina as well as the first Brazilian actress to win in 2025. Coincidentally, she is the daughter of actress Fernanda Montenegro, who was the first Brazilian actress to be nominated for the award in 1999 with her role in Central Station.
See also
* Academy Award for Best Actress
* Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Actress
* Independent Spirit Award for Best Female Lead
* BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role
* Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Comedy or Musical
* Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role
